Situation1: They notice a few swimmers occasionally drifting toward deeper water but no immediate danger arises.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I sat perched on my lifeguard chair, eyes scanning the pool, the whistle cool against my lips. The sun was relentless, and the swimmers below seemed content, though a few kept drifting toward the deep end. I knew my job—never let my guard down, not even for a second. But my phone buzzed in my bag, a reminder that my volunteer shift at the community center started in fifteen minutes. I was supposed to be there on time, setting an example, but I couldn’t just leave the pool unattended. I glanced at the clock, heart pounding. Other volunteers could cover the start of my shift, but I was the only lifeguard on duty right now. My supervisor expected unwavering vigilance, but the center counted on my reliability too. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait. I gripped the armrest, torn between duty and commitment, knowing I had to choose.
